The organization has consistently lived up to their value of respect for people...providing competitive compensation and benefits, and assuring that when layoffs occur, that those who are severed, are prepared for the transition.  The quality of the work environment is often heavily influenced by direct leadership/management, and I have been very fortunate to work alongside some of the very best leaders I have come across.
cons: A lack of continuity/frequent adjustments with regards to territory boundaries and account responsibilities has effectively equated to hitting the reset button on performance in a number of geographies.  Pfizer is attempting to remain change agile, but in many situational examples, the sheer size of the organization often precludes local level input and influence on decisions that would further the greater enterprise.

review_title: Leaving was the greatest thing that happened to my career
pros: Compensation, retirement benefits, stable stock, recognized resume name (though often the butt of a joke these days). Work-life balance
cons: Often silo'd into small roles with little room to learn and develop. "Small cog in big machine" feeling. Checkboxes over smart science. Andover and Groton sites are like taking valium. Nepotism and gaming the system more important for success. Constant organizational change.  Lack of age, gender and racial diversity at the sen principal scientist+ range. Resources cut every year. Demoralized researchers. Internal R&D is not important to C-suite.

pros: The training and the experience you get working @ Pfizer is priceless. As it is the # Multi National Company, you take part in ensuring that you defend its throne. The industry is very challenged, it brings out the best in you. The benefits you get especially healthcare benefit is the best.
cons: The level of commitment should not go below 100%. The balance between work and personal life is not possible. You have to go the extra mile always. With local companies eating chunks of our business because of pricing advantage, we tend to see the purpose of what we're here for in the first place. Life is our life's work.

review_title: It was a good learning experience and was happy to be associated with this great organization
pros: The company always encouraged best Innovation and Transparency. The upper management always there to listen and help their colleagues by providing conducive environment to give their best and enjoy the job fully.
cons: The career progress was limited. The RBM's have acted as impediments in the Business growth and also not caring their subordinates in terms of overall approach to the business. I would like the top management to evaluate the ground realities and be correct in deciding on the advise of the RBM's.

review_title: A good place to work but difficult to get things done
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: Large organization long term career plan, if you are able to make it through all the cuts constantly happening in the organization.
cons: They have been in a state of re organization for the last 6 years.  They cut back on people and jobs every year until recently now cutting every 6 months.  Difficult environment to grow and feel valued.  Not a good time to join Pfizer.

review_title: I worked for Pfizer 18+ years in various  sales and sales management capacities, and participated in 21 product launchs
pros: During the days of blockbuster medications and huge profits, innovation and initiative were celebrated and rewarded. I worked with some of the finest managers who were gifted leaders and found a way to tap into each individuals strengths. Their focus was positive development and continuous improvement.  You never needed to to 'keep your head down', but rather your opinion was required and expected. Having worked in a healthy work culture, you can recognize it anywhere, and also become quickly aware when the culture is not aligned with the stated business goals.
cons: Respect for people became  a lost core value. Leaders left Pfizer and were replaced by management governed by greed and desperate, dishonest yes men.

pros: Pfizer is still one of the best companies to work for.  Benefits are great.  Overall, the culture is inclusive and people are treated with respect. I enjoyed most of my 15 years there.
cons: There is a change in culture that is leading to the frail in the fabric of what most of us felt was a closely knit family.  Most of the efforts to fix human capital problems seems to be just another flavor of the month.   Loyalty is a thing of the past.  Expect long hours and lots of meetings.

pros: Pfizer's benefits are a plus.  Pharmaceutical Reps are paid well and work schedules are somewhat flexible.
cons: Pfizer operates like the military, but without the same job security.  There is little employee empowerment or creativity, and the opportunity for growth and development is lacking.  In addition, employees are treated very differently, depending on the Regional Manager and their style.

job_title: Senior Therapeutic Sales Representative in Memphis, TN
pros: The money and the benefits.The base pay is good if you have been with the company long enough bnut bonuses are lacking.
cons:
Stability, this company doesn't seem to know where it's going or how soon it will get there. Hold on for a roller coaster ride!
Right now there is such turmoil. The managers are so worried about their jobs they are leaving us alone. Some division can not compare their primary product to the competition. It used to be compare and win, now it is hope and pray!  If you think I am a "disgruntled slacker" you are wrong. I have 2 vpcs in the last 4 years. I just hate to see what this company has become compared to what it used to be.

review_title: I love my work, but I'm not always in love with my company.
pros: Friendly office atmosphere and a welcoming atitutde towrds new ideas. Continuous improvement is encouraged and sponsored regularly. The benefits packages are of the best offered in the corporate environment. A social, inclusive environment which may extend past the "work friends" relationship.
cons: Many shifts in resource/departmental organization which at times paralyzed real work from being accomplished. Internal political maneuvering is common at the upper and mid-upper levels, sometimes to the detriment of the those reporting up.

pros: Free Pfizer drugs, ability to commiserate with other inmates.
cons:
Pfizer got rid of most of its administrative staff  so that the execs could keep their jobs and hefty salaries.  In return, they all agreed to become administratively independent.  Unfortunately the execs still believe that the one and only team assistant is their personal assistant and require instant responses to their demands even though the one and only assistant is receiving similar demands from 20 other people.  They try to get their demands met instantly through chastisement and badgering, which is a sub-optimal management style.  If the one and only assistant pushes back, s/he is maligned.  

 Believing that the company can function properly without adequate administrative staff is misguided.  There are too many bad business practices to track here, so I won't get into the sadistic systems.  Suffice it to say that Pfizer has become the Walmart of the pharmaceutical industry.  Administrative candidates and AstraZeneca beware!

pros: Solid and agressive company with good business oriented mentality culture for a pharmaceutical company so full of technical/scientific background people.
cons: I became part of Pfizer with the recent acquisition of Wyeth so comparing both companies, I have to admit that Wyeth was a much more organized company with a bigger commitment to doing things right that Pfizer.  A bit dissapointed of Pfizer, I was expecting more from such a successful pharma company.  I guess their success relies more on their good pipeline of products and their R&D.  In manufacturing they have a lot to learn from Wyeth or other companies I have worked for before like J&J.

review_title: It was a great opportunity to learn how to adapt in an ever changing R&D environment within the pharmaceutical industry.
pros:
- The opportunity to discover and develop new medicines .  
- Generally, highly committed colleagues who had a real passion about the work they do.
cons: - There never seemed to be enough time allowed to see the results of the changes that were implemented.  The cycle time is long within this industry, yet significant changes in the research strategy seemed to occur on a 18 month cycle.

review_title: I had a great run, but I am happy to be gone.
pros: Pfizer, historically was a great company to work for.  Excellent values, integrity, innovative and with a mission that helped to serve humanity.  there are still lots of god people, but the pressures of the business have changed the culture for the worse.
cons: While the company still has significant strength and financial resources.  The lack of a coherent strategy and the relentless cost cutting and downsizing have created a very stressful culture.  The mission has shifted from helping humanity and running a good business to "it's all about the money."  Ian has a major mountain to climb.  He is doing better than I thought he would - figures an "old time Pfizer" guy  might make the right difference.

pros:
benefits team atmosphere ,Holidays


great pay.
cons: Pfizer continues to gobble up its competition leaving thousands of colleagues unemployed or underemployed. Some have spent 20-30 years working faithfully at the site and have to restart life again at 50-60 years old . I am sorry to say that once you are over a certain age companies pretend you do not exist even if you are the best candidate for the job

pros: Good name to have on the CV, learn about pharma politics game-of-thrones
cons: They make a point of no jerks because there are plenty of them. Constant layoffs result in a toxic competitive environment where your hiring manager is paranoid you will replace him so he silos you, steals your ideas and bad mouths you in front of the team. His manager is paranoid that he will replace him so you will then be used as ammunition. So so so incredibly stressful. Morale is low. Headless chickens who would otherwise be really smart and can do great things.

pros: I greatly appreciated the friendly working environment. Peers and superiors were especially courteous and respectful with one another and shared resources ideas and suggestions. I received feedback and guidance while on the job which was helpful.
cons: There were some organizational changes afoot that colleagues found distracting. This may have led to a certain amount of concern around 'turf'. It was all very subtle, but people were occasionally on edge about their place in the organization and the amount of respect perceived by their peers. For the most part, this did not get out of hand, but rather was an occasional source of stress.

pros: As a contractor, I had a flexible schedule.  The department had decent co-workers and a laid-back atmosphere.
cons: When is a contractor no longer a contractor?  I would say five years is excessive.  I understand Pfizer changed that and contractors are only allowed to stay one year.  Perhaps this is a better policy, so there is no more dangling of the carrot.

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good brand, good HQ location in midtown Manhattan, open to flexible work arrangements
cons:
The company is a big, ever changing mess.  Constant turnover at leadership levels, either due to restructuring, layoffs or people leaving makes it very difficult to get traction, either on projects or in professional growth.  Just when I felt I had established a rapport with a manager I got a new one and had to start over.  

Zero emphasis on people development; this is not a culture of managing down, the people who advance are the ones who focus on managing up, even if they ignore their direct reports.

If can be almost comical how much time leaders spend jockeying for position against each other  rather than collaborating on goals that increase value.

review_title: Great benefits, some great people, no job security
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: I worked in a small division that had a great culture and everyone was very focused on the task at hand.  Great benefits and work/life balance and we had a lot of fun in the group I worked with, not common in the larger organization.  Benefits are great.
cons: Constant reorganizations and changing business plans create an environment where you never know what you will be doing 6 months/1 year from now.  Different divisions are very protective of there work so collaboration and communication is very difficult.

pros: Nice to be able to work for a company that develops and sells such an important product.  We enhance the quality of life and treat conditions that are to the benefit of people and this is a very, very compelling reason to work in this area.  Good co-workers and the proper equipment to do your job.
cons: Large company with strong competition from generics.   Generics have the potential to erode profits in the future and this is stressful for current employees who often wonder what will happen when patents expire.  There are layoffs and consolidation that does not help morale and can be demoralizing.

review_title: Typical slow bureaucratic org addicted to restructuring, decent ethics
job_title: Business Technology Manager in Jersey City, NJ
pros: I feel good about Pfizer as a pharma company compared to many of its peers that are stained by involvement with the opioid epidemic. There's a good emphasis on ethics and values but I roll my eyes when I receive ridiculous company emails with topics like "Awkward Thanksgiving table conversations: how to discuss pharmaceutical drug pricing."
cons: Every two years there's a reorg or restructuring so you're always working through the churn created by those. The handling of the Consumer Healthcare spinoff has been reprehensible: a solid, well-performing division was dragged through uncertainty for a year and a half, causing attrition on top of a headcount reduction and making it clear that we weren't valued for the diversification and good returns we provided to the company portfolio.

review_title: Great place to get Hands on Experience
pros: While working as a contractor at Pfizer, I have had the opportunity to get involved in many aspects of the projects I have been involved.  I have had the opportunity to be a team player where my input was saught at the tactical and strategic level.  The teams I worked with both Pfizer and other contractors were easy to work with and allowed me the freedom to my job without interference.
cons: Probably the biggest con is the fact that Pfizer has a policy where contractors have to roll off the books after a year. Although tools such as requirements management were lacking, I was afforded the opportunity to develop a tool to support the requirements efforts.

review_title: Culture has changed for the worse
pros:
Excellent compensation and benefits - though benefits are being reduced
Interresting and challenging work
cons:
Herd and yes-man mentality creeping in
Promotion and retention is becoming more and more based on who you know and not compentency - this has historically been an issue but is more noticable as economic conditions require cutbacks

review_title: Pfizer was a terrific company to work for.
job_title: Professional Healthcare Representative in Cincinnati, OH
pros: I really enjoyed most of the people I worked with. All were well rounded, professional, educated and, for the most part, enthusiastic and hard working. The company initially was completely committed to the success of the sales force and spared no expense to ensure all sales needs were met. The salaries, bonuses and benefits were second to none. The support in the field was superb as well.
cons: My career ended when I was laid off in 2009. There was a lack of product in the pipeline to maintain sales when medicines lost their patent exclusivity. Job security and growth continue to be an area of concern.

job_title: National Account Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Talent, resources and most importantly, the products, to make the work meaningful, rewarding and challenging. Pfizer does offer significant development training opportunities, for those with ambition to secure and pursue. We typically always have a seat at the table for important negotiations with customers. Great leadership for the most part.
cons: It may be a harsh truth, but people are disposable. Pfizer tends to take this to a point where we are just numbers and not people. Certainly not family. Truly caring for your people is a way to improve the culture to a point where everyone WANTS to work harder, do more and succeed. This is most evident in our R&D group, but even Sales and Marketing. Years of layoffs and restructures have taken a toll.

job_title: Manufacturing Quality Supervisor in Austin, TX
pros:
There are a lot of growth opportunities for someone who is very hard working. 
There are lots of people who have been in the plant for a very long time and are very knowledgeable. You just need to know where to find them and get information from them.
cons:
There are a lot of politics that come with the Job. There will be pressure from management of all different departments trying to influence decisions you make from a QA standpoint.
At the time I was there, tons of changes were going on and it made it difficult to hold things steady. The department was disorganized and still trying to find out how many roles it could take on.

review_title: Great company - 14 years working with some very smart people
job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros:
I spent 14 years at Pfizer (even though I didn't think I would be there that long), and here are the things I really liked:
- very smart people, some of the best I've met in the industry; very committed to bringing cures to market
- a global footprint that helps you understand how one makes and sells medicines across the world (so some very strong global exposure)
- great benefits and recognition of the need for work-life balance, though work can be intense at times
- a learning environment that allows colleagues to grow themselves. It's not just a paycheck at the end of the day - growing skills and learning is what kept me happy
- commitment to compliance and "doing right by the patient" regardless of other drivers
- focus on diversity; the leadership team is diverse, the board is diverse, and every hiring decision is reviewed with a lens of inclusion and diversity. It's not just women and minorities, but hiring with a focus on getting different viewpoints and talents on the table
- New York City (though that's a con too - it's getting harder to commute in from the suburbs)! But the energy in the city is amazing, and I miss it.
cons:
- lots of reorganization; we restructured almost every year from the mid-2000s onwards. Sometimes it was needed but it was also disruptive at other times. Not sure there's a way to avoid it given Wall Street pressures
- large company politics, which one will see in any large pharma. By and large, it worked out ok for me, but it may not be a place for someone who cannot maneuver in such an environment
- commuting into the city steadily got worse over the years. Perhaps it will get easier after the new tunnel and the Amtrak renovations are done.

review_title: Ovarall satisfied - get to do what you want when you want
pros: Challenging work - you are largely in charge of your own destiny and can find interesting / challenging projects to fill your time with
cons: Layoffs and plant closings make motivation difficult.   Advancement is at the whim of management - sure this is always the case - but past a certain level it depends largely on what upper management thinks of you.  If you are a contrarian or if you don't really care what management thinks of you, you need to think of another way to get recognized - and even then it probably won't work.  "Yes men" rule.

pros: These have been absolutely the best people with whom I have ever worked!!!! There is no challenge too large or unique that they will not take on and just completely "crush it!" - Overachieve
cons: Leadership - senior level for site andtheir superiors, are out of touch with the shop floor workers and too wrapped up in their egos! No decisions can be decentralized - everything is very much dictated and micro-managed in spite of the massive amounts of talent and creativity at the Site!

review_title: Look elsewhere unless you are looking for a go no where 9-5 job
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: work life balance is excellent.  The challenge associated with work is minimal
cons: Pfizer provides minimal to no upward mobility for their employees.  The company is constantly reorganizing and as part of these reorganizations they are loosing the core identity.  This only matters because a large number of the senior leaders (Sr Director Level) are oldschool Pfizer/Warner Lambert/Pharmacia employees which steers direction of the groups.  Organization is hurting in short term

review_title: Pfizer is a great company to work for. It has the most diverse portfolio in the industry and strong worldwide presence.
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Collegeville, PA
pros: It has strong training programs, competitive compensation packages and excellent benefits. Pfizer is in a transformation phase what creates several opportunities for career growth.
cons: Downsides are job instability and delay by senior management in announcing decisions about the organizational structure moving forward. The work environment continues to be stressful and there is an overlap between legacy-Wyeth and legacy-Pfizer operational procedures, what makes daily work activities difficult. Legacy-Pfizer benefits are still not fully available to legacy-Wyeth employees.

review_title: Not the best place to work if you like having a personal life
job_title: Professional Healthcare Representative II in Brooklyn, NY
pros: The Benefits package, decent salary
cons: LONG hours, little or no work/life balance, managers promote based on company politics more than actual competence.

review_title: Pfizer: Not A Great Place to Work
job_title: Human Resources Director  in Kalamazoo, MI
pros: Pfizer has a great benefits program with excellent coverage for all drugs and almost every health issue under the sun. Good internal relocation package, as well.
cons: Pfizer is a combination of three cultures, all dysfunctional. Also, there is a sense of $$ entitlement among senior management. If you're in NYC, the benefits are plush (car service, helicopters, nights at hotels) but the rest of the company is meant to scrape by and endure layoffs. Seems unfair.

job_title: QC Chemist in Terre Haute, IN
pros: Pay is good and benefits are excellent.  For example, when I worked at Pfizer, they implemented a new policy at the site for a 6-week paid PATERNITY leave.  Unreal. I started out with 3 weeks of paid vacation plus most holidays were paid.  If you did work on a holiday, you were compensated very well, usually double-time pay. They are flexible regarding lay-offs in my experience.  The site at which I worked closed, but they offered to transfer me to another site or give me a severance package.
cons: Not too many complaints that I can think of.  It was the best job I have ever had.  I did get a little bored which motivated me to move on to graduate school.

pros:
- Intelligent, collaborative colleagues
- Opportunity for career progression and decent mobility within the organization
- Great place to learn new skill sets, build on your current experience, and grow professionally
cons:
- "Work-life integration" rather than work-life balance
- Depending on your role, work hours can be onerous
- Institutional inertia at times prevents positive change (great new ideas are encouraged but sometimes subsequently suppressed)
- Slow to fire colleagues that lack competence for their role and/or have abrasive personalities to the detriment of the colleagues around them (negative impact to otherwise positive culture)

review_title: Be careful what you wish for.
pros: The Pay is not too bad. There are opportunities to advance but there a lot of people who dont want you to. There are people that make a lot of money but it seems to have more to do with luck than any kind of professional skill
cons: the hours are horrible. there is no balance between personal life and work life. they expect a lot of you and if you offer any kind of pushback then you will be forwned upon. they arent secretive about it either. there are times when it is so blatant it is borderline offensive. professionalism is definitely not a strong point for this company. i need to get out!.

pros: Can gain a lot of experience in the pharmaceutical sector. Would guess that as a new person just starting out, a great place to learn.
cons: Has gone from first to worst as a place for reps to work in record time. The culture of smart, consultative representatives has been systematically beaten down and/or replaced with a huge "promotional" force of micro-managed box checkers. For the reps, by necessity the customers (physicians) are last on a long priority list - first priority is always the internal Pfizer customer - Management. The sheer layers of management are astounding. Sad, really.

review_title: It was a Great Company to work for..
pros: People were highly talented both in HO and field force, culture was professional, lots of learning was there.
cons: Market evolved but Pfizer India didnt. Lack of good people in sr management  and even the sales and marketing is very weak. pfizer values are put on stake by some. Lots of beaurocarcy. No proper plan while launching branded generic, launching 20 - 30 branded generics over a period of 2 years is Not Pfizer India style.

review_title: Depressing culture, everyone just going through the motions
pros: Pay is good but only if you get overtime.  Benefits are generous.
cons: Lots of disgruntled people with poor outlooks on life.  People know that they are stuck in this job for life because no one else in the area pays as well.  If you make waves, management will mess with you so it's best to just keep quiet and don't report anything you see.  People will not follow SOP and will intentionally cut corners at the risk of product safety.  Lots of theft throughout the plant in Kalamazoo.  Lock up your belongings.

job_title: Senior Therapeutic Sales Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Talented, innovative group of self-directed individuals who are always willing to help one another. This allows continuous opportunity to learn and grow. Great compensation. Investment in the best training out there, which is why Pfizer is known for having the best representatives.
cons: The climate of the pharmaceutical industry has changed over the years, with layoffs always looming. It used to be that the majority of employees stayed with the company over 20 years. Now staying for at least 10 years is rare. Not a lot of opportunity to advance in other departments if you start out in the sales division.

review_title: Not as good as it used to be...
pros: Good benefits and pay and most of the people are great to work with.  Company still offers a pension plan which is good considering most companies don't these days.  The health benefits are very good and probably could not be matched by very many companies.
cons: With all the mergers and acqusitions the systems aren't all that great.  Need more emphasis on integrating all companies and systems together instead of patching things as they fail.  Most  of the systems are antiquated and need to be updated.  Most of the manufacturing jobs are being cut in the US and sent overseas.  Lack of execution trying to replace products that are going off patent.

review_title: As long as they are not laying off, it is a great company.
job_title: Therapeutic Specialty Representative in Sarasota, FL
pros:
Large Company, Great Benefits and Salary.
They do have top of the line products and great name recognition.  The budgets are down recently, but there is still alot of money to spend to drive business.
cons:
There have been a lot of layoffs....many large aquisitions - makes for low job security.
The new pharma guidelines headed by pfizer are counterproductive to being able to make an influence.
Lawyers rule the roost in sales....everything need to be approved by legal and it is monitered.  Any speaker programs can be spot audited and there are many many rules which make it difficult for those who want to sell off of anything but the company approved script.

review_title: Best job that I have ever had.
job_title: Senior Corporate Counsel in Montreal, QC
pros: Competitive salary and good benefits.  Because the corporation is a matrix organization, there are many opportunities to work in different departments.  Advancement seems to be fair.  Flexible hours are also a benefit.  Resources are never an issue, although budget is becoming more of a managed affair.  Educational assistance plan is very generous.  Directors also are provided a vehice and gas card.
cons: Large organization that tends to switch strategies every 1.5 years.  The reporting chain is somewhat artifcial due to its regional groupings.  The sales force is somewhat cavalier.  HR is very large, but offers little personal service.  Corporate messaging sometimes lack sincerity.

review_title: 8 years of greatness, 2 years of missery
job_title: Senior Automation Engineer in Barceloneta, PR
pros: Values Culture, very skilled Employees, Interesting and challenging work experience due to Multiple Operations (not boring at all), good salaries and benefits.
cons: After the latest adquisition, an excellent place to work became a nightmare.  There is no balance between work and life, not enough employees to preform the tasks necessary, moving to sub-contract most positions leading to lack of expertisse by Pfizer Employees, lack of respect to Employees due to aggressive non-inclusive management,  had become a battlefield between Pfizer Legacy Management and former Wyeth Management,  No-career growth path.

pros: Many expert professionals dedicated to good outcomes.  Great compensation and benefits.
